content: hi my name is jonathan elements i'm a
freelance web developer based near amsterdam in the netherlands you can
find me mostly on twitter when I am at GFI element I've been a service and gems
tech enthusiasts for some time I organized the serverless Amsterdam
meetup series for a while and back in the good old days when we could actually
attend conferences in person remember those I was involved in
organizing a yearly conference that grew to be quite popular over the past 10
years in fact it became such a popular event to attend that ticket sales were
becoming a bit of a problem in 2016 a conference sold out around 600 tickets
in under 2 minutes and the next year it sold out in less than 30 seconds now
this is a great problem for conference organisers to have but people were
getting really annoyed but not being able to obtain a ticket in a normal
orderly fashion surface would be slow there will be queues and delays things
would crash our previous ticketing solution was a hosted platform that it
couldn't handle this load well in fact during the rush to get a limited supply
of early bird tickets the service couldn't keep up with demand counters
went haywire and that resulted in over selling so more early bird tickets were
sold than the limit that was set and because we felt more or less compelled
to honor these ticket sales we took quite substantial financial hit now
there are a lot of excellent ticket selling services out there some are not
so excellent and I'm sure you can find something that really works great for
you and your event for me as a developer of course there's
only one way to fix this problem which was to build my own ticket shop and a
gem stack was my dog food a static website using as few dynamic bells and
whistles as possible in JavaScript or any other language
in fact I built three things a static website an API with endpoints serving
JSON and a database storage normal kind of the Holy Trinity over decoupled
jamjam stack website of course there's a lot more to it but these things come at
build time so before you even deploy your website here's a couple of things
that work really well in keeping that really fast and performed stick to a
simple single purpose playing JavaScript components model you may be comfortable
with a lot more going on client-side using react or view or the other one but
for this application we really didn't need any of that stick to simple single
purpose API handlers deployed as serverless functions on AWS lambda in
our case but there are other options are available we put the whole thing
together using some old school friends gulp and no jokes templating yes gulp
I'm I am that old the best way to keep things fast and performant is to
pre-render as much as possible a good example of that for example example for
example is a list of countries in a form where you ask users to fill in their
address there's usually a list of countries that they can choose from and
you see these lists going back and forth over the line in
HTTP responses a lot and it's always the same long list of countries so if you
move that to the template which you render before you deploy it to your
static website Python then you only have to build it once you can serve it fast
and often after that in fact to overcome the overselling problem of the early
bird tickets I kind of pre-rendered these tickets in the database as well so
instead of keeping track with a counter in the queue increment in the database
which you could in theory if things go wrong keep incrementing to infinity or
even at an empty table that you fill with records for every ticket that you
sell
I had a table that had 600 records in it representing the tickets and updating
those as they were sold you can't update records that don't
exist and relational database models are very good at keeping these things
accurate so that kind of solved the problem of over selling the tickets and
kept things going quite fast from the user perspective stick to a simple flow
logic you could build something that's really complex on the client-side but we
kind of stuck to just the simplest things that are possible on the web
links that you can click and then follow yes it's amazing to a new page for
example this might look like a sophisticated complex personalized
template but it's very very generic there's not much going on here and those
links are just that links to another page so there's this is
this was the downloading your tickets page is one of the fastest before in
pages because there is really nothing going on there so simple templates no
virtual dome in this case just small holes in these templates that are
updated with personalized information coming in from the API and all of that
makes for a super-fast website there's almost nothing easier than letting other
people do the work as long as they tell you when they're done and they provide
you a way to get to the result of that work Web books are your friend they're
great for this we uploaded some of the work and there's still no servers to
manage but we do get the benefits of that work now this super simplified
approach may not work when you scale things up to enterprise level there is
no CMS in this platform the content is hard-coded into HTML templates and while
that's for developers something to very quickly and easily update when you have
content editors they don't have access to that code and then things become
quite involved even to fix simple small content issues a little typos also in
the title of this talk I mentioned no cookies and this is truth so we use
session identifiers being able to distinguish between users in URLs don't
do that that was not a good idea and it means that I can say no cookies but it's
just not a very good I think to do from a security point of view also the flow
logic in this application it was hard coded so you go from A to B
to C there is no way to distinguish four different users to do different things
in the application so it worked really well for this but it may not work very
well and you have something more complex to do one thing that you can do and that
you may not want to do but that you definitely can do with a gem stack
website is you can deploy to production during peak load it's something that we
did once or twice when we thought that was necessary there are no services to
stop and start there's no processes things that need to
cycle there's no warmup time things are just files and we update them when it
was the most critical to do so that works really well so go ahead deploy to
production on a Friday afternoon what's the worst that can happen thank you for
having me thank you for being here or there I'll be hanging around in the in
